name: Memory Repatterning
description: Techniques to disrupt negative thought loops and reframe past trauma memories.

cards.title: Reality Check Exercises
cards.description: Training the mind to differentiate between past trauma and present safety.
bulletpoints: When intrusive memories arise, pause and list three things that confirm you are in the present, not the past.
Use safe space visualization to reinforce emotional security and distance from past distress.
Practice daily affirmation training by reminding yourself, 'I am safe, I am here, and the past cannot harm me now.'

cards.title: Memory Rewriting Techniques
cards.description: Altering emotional associations tied to traumatic memories.
bulletpoints: Reimagine the traumatic memory as if you had power over the situation, mentally shifting yourself into a position of control.
Use guided imagery to introduce new, positive elements into the memory, diluting its emotional weight.
Reduce the emotional charge by visualizing the memory in black-and-white or shrinking it to a small, distant image.

cards.title: Symbolic Replacement Therapy
cards.description: Replacing painful memory symbols with empowering or neutral ones.
bulletpoints: Identify the core symbol in a painful memory and replace it with a more empowering or neutral image.
Engage in a personal ritual, such as burning an old representation of pain and replacing it with a new symbol of healing.
Use metaphor reprocessing by turning past experiences into a meaningful story where you emerge stronger.

cards.title: Narrative Reframing
cards.description: Reconstructing personal stories to empower rather than disempower.
bulletpoints: Write a new version of your story where you are the hero overcoming adversity, rather than the victim.
Shift the focus from what was done to you, to what strengths you developed because of your experiences.
Engage in self-dialogue, telling yourself that your past does not define your future unless you allow it.

cards.title: Anchoring to Positive Memory Triggers
cards.description: Strengthening neural pathways tied to joy, safety, and empowerment.
bulletpoints: Create a physical or visual anchor, such as an object or image, that represents a positive, empowering memory.
When facing distress, focus on the anchor and immerse yourself in the emotions of that positive memory.
Strengthen the anchor by pairing it with deep breathing and self-affirming thoughts to reinforce emotional stability.

cards.title: Desensitization Through Repetition
cards.description: Gradually reducing the emotional intensity of painful memories.
bulletpoints: Expose yourself to the memory in small, controlled doses while practicing deep relaxation techniques.
Repeat the memory while actively changing its details each time, slowly removing its emotional grip.
Over time, the repeated exposure dulls the brainâ€™s automatic distress response, reducing fear and anxiety.

cards.title: Transformational Visualization
cards.description: Using the power of mental imagery to reconstruct past experiences.
bulletpoints: Visualize a scenario where you are protected, supported, and safe in moments where you once felt helpless.
Surround traumatic memories with light, dissolving fear and replacing it with a sense of security.
Imagine yourself stepping outside the memory and rewriting its outcome to reclaim power and confidence.

cards.title: Subconscious Dialogue Reprogramming
cards.description: Replacing internalized negative narratives with empowering self-dialogue.
bulletpoints: Listen to your self-talk and identify phrases or beliefs rooted in past trauma.
Replace limiting beliefs with affirmations such as 'I am worthy,' 'I am free,' and 'I control my own story.'
Reinforce these new beliefs through repetition, writing them down, and saying them out loud daily.

cards.title: Sensory Memory Diffusion
cards.description: Detaching from traumatic memories through sensory control.
bulletpoints: Alter the texture, sound, or colors in your memory to neutralize emotional intensity.
Imagine the event happening in slow motion or as if it were playing on a distant screen to create psychological distance.
Engage in deep breathing and grounding techniques to prevent reattachment to the distressing memory.

cards.title: Time Perspective Recalibration
cards.description: Training the brain to perceive traumatic events as distant, rather than present.
bulletpoints: Imagine placing the memory into a book and closing it, symbolizing its place in the past.
Visualize walking forward on a timeline, looking back at the memory as a small, distant event.
Recognize that time has passed, and with it, the ability for that moment to affect you in the present.
